title: For between 8 July 2020 and 7 August 2020, how many fatalities related to political violence and protest events will ACLED record in Ethiopia?
preds: Updating based on current figures (only 21 fatalities recorded so far).
Only 21 deaths have been recorded thus far, so unless some large event occurs before August 7th, it is unlikely more than 100 will ultimately die in this time frame.

Revising based on ACLED data because seems most deaths related to Hachalu Hundessa's occurred before 8 July. Only 1 death since July 8th, acc. to acled. Drastic change because I misread the question and didnt consider when Hachalu Hundessa was assassinated (June 29th).
Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project over the last few years I think COVID-19 will have an impact
Protests continue and there is still tension between tribes. Could get violent. Hedging some.
As of today 23 July, the ACLED data lists 4. I hope this continues and there are few fatalities.

-The government cut/control the internet 
-The government arrested around 1000 of people
-They start filling Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam and use this politically
Latest fatalities as of 07/14 (3) aren't even related to politics.
Assuming political violence spikes sharply after the initial incident and then drops dramatically (I don't have concrete evidence for this claim).

Given a recent spike 100-500 seem to be a sweat spot. No data past that Jul 8 but 300 seems like a typical spot to jump to. After jump happens, it makes 2-3 months to drop below 100. Why should this time be different?
Chart: http:\\shorturl.at/boGLU
Data: https://acleddata.com/data-export-tool/
Despite my earlier post I checked the numbers on ACLED an one on July 8 and nothing after. It is not to say things are not still tense but I have seen no mention of further mass violence.
Backing off dome. Things are still volatile. https://moziak.africa/ethiopia-protests-whats-going-on/
Still dicey but might hang on this short period. https://qz.com/africa/1881323/ethiopias-oromo-tensions-erupt-in-violence-for-abiy/

Incrementing down a bit seeing that ACLED has updated with a single fatality in a riot on 07/08. So prima facie, the violence is not over -- I'll keep an eye on this and bounce up if another week goes by without chaos.
Internet being partially restored. Next couple of days are key. If Protests do not flair again going to go even more on low end.
between direct military action, internet blockage, and now the apprehension of the murder suspects, ire and suspicion remains, but riots and protest activity have plummeted.
I see none after July 3rd. Since not ongoing going to go low.

Of the fourteen discrete months in the last hundred years where Ethiopia saw more than 100 fatalities in riots, protests, or violence against citizens, 85% saw the next month with fewer than 100 fatalities.

At the moment, the flashpoint is restricted.  There seems to be a steady outrage over the killing of Hundessa, but it does not seem from reports to be widening into a more generalized cultural problem.   To be blunt, there's only so much canon-fodder to throw at authorities under those circumstances.  And as protests go on, those who don't mind dying do, while the rest establish an equilibrium with authorities.   I'd be a little surprised if it tipped 500, therefore.

The Queerroo of Ethiopia actually resemble a slightly less militant version of the EPRDF,  who toppled the Derg regime in 1987.  And aside from the scale of Derg atrocities, the EPDRF subsequently manifested similar vices.   Abiy Ahmed and Jawar Mohammed initially banded against the EPDRF but succumbed to the characteristic chaos defined by Ethiopian politics.  Overthrowing the EPDRF government together led to a fragile Oromo political base dependent on an immature Queerroo following.  Abiy Ahmed won the role as Prime Minister and Jawar Mohammed eventually splintered against the new Abiy government. Moving forward, the new gen Queerroo are still defined as young, single men charged with energy.   Explosive outbursts currently define the protests and the internet has proven to be a unifying tool by the anti-authoritative Queerroo against the Abiy led government. Abiy recently shut down the internet and increased military presence.  Upon  first impression through the lens of western culture, it appears to create the potential for additional unrest, but so far prevented the crystallization of another civil war.  I don’t see another Arab Spring but can imagine sporadic clashes.  Down deep the Queerroo know Abiy is Oromo, but have expectations of the government that cannot be fulfilled. @ManuPV do you see escalation??

3500 arrested, the internet and TV stations shut-down to keep them from fanning flames. No one knows who did the assassination at this time. Internet reopening today. Two things going on. The Prime Minister is Oromo tribe and that group is asking for more autonomy in their areas. There is some ethnic tension in the country around what power each ethnic group has. The assassinated singer was Oromo too. The other possibility is Ethiopia is going to fill an area with water to create hydroelectric power much to Egypt’s anger. They may be trying to destabilize the government. 
In any case there is a protest being called for on Friday in the Capital. We shall see where things go after that.

Initial until I can look-up ACLED data. Does not work well on iphone Safari. Today’s news says the internet has been turned off and 238 have died in protests. Either things will now cool or ramp-up. More later.

Hattip to @tccoleman26 for making me aware that I didn't take into account the base rate [1], and his helpful comment [2]. Accordingly, I'v re-allocated probabilties to the <100 fatalities option. I still expect >100 fatalities due to the volatile situation. Recent media reports indicate there were ~240 fatalities (rather than just ~160) and more than 3,500 people arrested [3,4,5]. Ethnic conflicts between Oromo and Amhara may as well heat up. The prominent Oromo activist Jawar Mohammed and 30 of his supporters have been arrested - probably as an attempt to calm things down. We'll see if that'll work. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1074344
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1074309
[3] https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/death-toll-ethiopia-violence-singer-killing-hits-239-200708075014258.html
[4] https://apnews.com/761ba72fed4ba76cabbcbfadebced6bd
[5] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/ethiopias-week-of-unrest-sees-239-dead-3500-arrested/2020/07/08/8eb30952-c100-11ea-8908-68a2b9eae9e0_story.html
This will cool off! Rage is a fresh product...........will expire!

If your read over the fatalities from the past 6 months, there has been an average of maybe 20 deaths  (if that) per month in Ethiopa. With the great exception being this past week with 89+ being killed as a result of the protests.  Which would put my normal probability around 80% for that category. However, if it were going to get into a the next bucket up, it would probably happen in spurts. Where there would be one rather large event of 50+ fatalities in one day, and then 10 deaths here and there, with some singular deaths here and there as it approached 0 on the time axis. Similar to a second order differntial equation at the Ts (Time to stability).

~160 people have been killed since the death of Hachalu Hundessa on June 29  [1] - these fatalities are, however, not included in the time frame of the question.  Protests are likely to continue in the next weeks. Depending on their longevity and the specific government response, there will be more (>500) or less fatalities (<500). Currently, it seems government forces won't deescalate as called for by international groups [2]. Nevertheless, international pressure may be critical to keep fatalities low. ~2300 people have been arrested so far ... so Abiy's government may be inclined to avoid large numbers of fatalities (>500 or even >1000) and consider more arrests in exchange. 4 weeks to go with a similar count would lead to ~640 fatalities. If things heat up, more fatalities won't be able to avoid (>1000). If things cool down, less fatalities are more probable (<500). [1] https://www.dw.com/en/ethiopia-death-toll-doubles-from-unrest-over-singers-murder/a-54059817
[2] https://www.dw.com/en/ethiopias-democratization-at-risk/a-54069213
